sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• adjustment not necessary when switching from IV to oral formulation
  • Bacteremia associated with intravascular line, Confirmed ampicillin- and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis/faecium: 600 mg IV every 12 hours; do not use empirically
  • Community acquired pneumonia: 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing) or for 7 to 21 days when MRSA-associated infection (guideline dosing)
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: (MRSA-associated) 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for a minimum of 8 weeks for osteomyelitis and 3 to 4 weeks for septic arthritis
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated: 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing), or for 7 to 14 days when MRSA-associated infection (guideline dosing)
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Uncomplicated: 400 mg ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Infective endocarditis: 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for a minimum of 8 weeks
  • Nosocomial pneumonia: 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing) or for 7 to 21 days when MRSA-associated (guideline dosing)
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium infection: 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 14 to 28 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• adjustment not necessary when switching from IV to oral formulation
  • Community acquired pneumonia: (12 years and older) 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Community acquired pneumonia: (birth through 11 years) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours for 10 to 14 days, not to exceed 600 mg/dose
  • Community acquired pneumonia: (preterm neonates less than 34 weeks of gestation) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours, increase to 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours by 7 days of life or sooner for suboptimal clinical response; recommended duration of treatment, 10 to 14 days
  • Community acquired pneumonia: (older than 3 months to younger than 12 years) 30 mg/kg/day IV or ORALLY in 3 divided doses (guideline dosing)
  • Community acquired pneumonia: (12 years and older) 20 mg/kg/day IV or ORALLY in 2 divided doses (guideline dosing)
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: (MRSA-associated) 12 years or older, 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours; younger than 12 years, 10 mg/kg/dose (MAX, 600 mg/dose) every 8 hours; duration is 4 to 6 weeks for osteomyelitis and 3 to 4 weeks for septic arthritis
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated: (12 years or older) 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated: (birth through 11 years) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours for 10 to 14 days (manufacturer dose), not to exceed 600 mg/dose (guideline)
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated: (birth through 11 years) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours (guideline dose)
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated: (preterm neonates less than 34 weeks of gestation) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours, increase to 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours by 7 days of life or sooner for suboptimal clinical response; recommended duration of treatment, 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Uncomplicated: (12 years and older) 600 mg ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Uncomplicated: (5 to 11 years) 10 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Uncomplicated: (birth through 4 years) 10 mg/kg ORALLY every 8 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Uncomplicated: (preterm neonates less than 34 weeks of gestation) 10 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours, increase to 10 mg/kg ORALLY every 8 hours by 7 days of life or sooner for suboptimal clinical response; recommended duration of treatment, 10 to 14 days
  • Infective endocarditis: 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours (MAX, 1200 mg/day) for a minimum of 8 weeks
  • Nosocomial pneumonia: (12 years and older) 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Nosocomial pneumonia: (birth through 11 years) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours for 10 to 14 days, not to exceed 600 mg/dose
  • Nosocomial pneumonia: (preterm neonates less than 34 weeks of gestation) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours, increase to 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours by 7 days of life or sooner for suboptimal clinical response; recommended duration of treatment, 10 to 14 days
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium infection: (12 years and older) 600 mg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours for 14 to 28 days
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium infection: (birth through 11 years) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours for 14 to 28 days
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium infection: (preterm neonates less than 34 weeks of gestation) 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 12 hours, increase to 10 mg/kg IV or ORALLY every 8 hours by 7 days of life or sooner for suboptimal clinical response; recommended duration of treatment, 14 to 28 days

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: no adjustment necessary
  • hemodialysis: administer dose after hemodialysis
  • hepatic impairment, mild to moderate (Child-Pugh class A or B): no adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Community acquired pneumonia
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Uncomplicated
  • Nosocomial pneumonia
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium infection
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Bacteremia associated with intravascular line, Confirmed ampicillin- and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis/faecium
  • Febrile neutropenia
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint
  • Infective endocarditis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant use of MAOIs or use within 2 weeks of taking an MAOI such as phenelzine or isocarboxazid
  • hypersensitivity to linezolid or any other component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- uncontrolled hypertension; use not recommended unless patients monitored for potential blood pressure increases
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- lactic acidosis has been reported; immediately evaluate patients who develop recurrent nausea or vomiting, unexplained acidosis, or a low bicarbonate level
  • -- symptomatic hypoglycemia has been reported in diabetic patients receiving concomitant insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents; dose adjustment or discontinuation may be required
  • -- thyrotoxicosis; use not recommended unless patients monitored for potential blood pressure increases
  • -- pheochromocytoma; use not recommended unless patients monitored for potential blood pressure increases
  • Hematologic:
  • -- myelosuppression in the form of anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia has been reported especially during treatment longer than 2 weeks; monitoring recommended
  • -- myelosuppression may occur in patients with chronic infection during concomitant or prior antibiotic therapy or with concomitant use of bone marrow suppression drugs; monitoring recommended
  • Neurologic:
  • -- convulsions may occur in patients with history or risk factors for seizure
  • -- peripheral and optic neuropathy may occur especially in patients treated longer than 28 days
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- visual disturbances such as changes in visual acuity or color vision, blurred vision, and visual field defects have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Other:
  • -- carcinoid syndrome; use not recommended unless clinically necessary
  • -- catheter-related bloodstream infections or catheter-site infections; use not recommended
  • -- serotonin syndrome with fatal cases has been reported with concomitant use of serotonergic agents; monitoring and immediate discontinuation of serotonergic agent required
  • -- phenylketonuria; oral suspension contains 20 mg phenylalanine per 5 mL
  • -- pediatric patients with CNS infections; use not recommended
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- concomitant use of indirectly or directly acting sympathomimetic agents such as pseudoephedrine, vasopressive agents such as epinephrine and norepinephrine, or dopaminergic agents such as dopamine and dobutamine is not recommended unless patients are monitored for potential blood pressure increases
  • -- concomitant use of SSRIs, tricyclic antidepressants, triptans, meperidine, bupropion, or buspirone not recommended unless clinically necessary; monitoring required if coadministration necessary

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (adult, 8.2% to 8.3%; pediatric, 1.6% to 10.8%), Nausea (adult, 5.1% to 6.6%; pediatric, 1.9% to 3.7%), Vomiting (adult, 2% to 4.3%; pediatric, 9.4%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (adult, 5.7% to 8.8%; pediatric, 0.9% to 6.5%)
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Lactic acidosis
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile diarrhea
  • Hematologic:Myelosuppression
  • Hepatic:Injury of liver
  • Neurologic:Peripheral neuropathy, Seizure
  • Ophthalmic:Disorder of optic nerve
  • Other:Serotonin syndrome

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Linezolid is an oxazolidinones that inhibits the bacterial ribosomal translation process, of aerobic Gram-positive bacteria and certain Gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria, by selectively binding to a site on the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit, thereby preventing initiation complex formation with the 70S ribosomal subunit.

sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral, adults: 1.03 to 1.12 hours
  • Tmax, IV, adults: 0.51 hours
  • Tmax, IV, pediatrics: 0.54 hours

  • Effects of food: Cmax delayed 1.5 to 2.2 hours and decreased about 17% with high-fat food; AUC (0 to infinity) not affected

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intravenous
    • administer over 30 to 120 minutes
    • compatible with D5W, NS, and LR
  • Oral
    • may be administered without regard to meals
    • (suspension) add 123 mL distilled water (final concentration, 100 mg/5 mL) in 2 portions, shaking between each portion
    • (suspension) after reconstitution, invert bottle gently 3 to 5 times before each use but do NOT shake; use within 21 days when stored at room temperature

10.mono:
• fever, symptomatic improvement
  • CBC, with differential, weekly
  • myelosuppression, signs/symptoms
  • persistent diarrhea and/or nausea/vomiting, potentially progressing to lactic acidosis, even as late as 2 months or more after last dose
  • visual impairment or changes; recommend visual function tests in patients taking linezolid for 3 months or longer and in all patients reporting new visual symptoms
  • seizure/convulsion activity
  • peripheral neuropathy, signs/symptoms
  • serotonin syndrome, particularly when given concomitantly with other serotonergic drugs

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
OXAZOLIDINONE ANTIBACTERIALS
USES: Linezolid is approved for the treatment of infections caused by various gram-positive organisms including vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Streptococcus agalactiae. Tedizolid phosphate is approved for the treatment of adults with acute bacterial skin and skin structure infections caused by susceptible gram-positive microorganisms of Staphylococcus aureus (including methicillin-resistant and susceptible isolates), Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus agalactiae, Streptococcus anginosus group (which includes S anginosus, S intermedius, and S constellatus) and Enterococcus faecalis. Eperezolid is not available in the United States. PHARMACOLOGY: Linezolid is an oxazolidinones that inhibits the bacterial ribosomal translation process, of aerobic Gram-positive bacteria and certain Gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria, by selectively binding to a site on the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit, thereby preventing initiation complex formation with the 70S ribosomal subunit. Tedizolid phosphate is the prodrug of tedizolid, an oxazolidinone antibiotic, which inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Human overdose information is limited. Overdose effects are anticipated to be an extension of adverse effects observed following therapeutic doses. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and headache. OTHER EFFECTS: Rash, toxic optic neuropathy and peripheral neuropathy, tongue discoloration, elevated liver enzymes, pseudomembranous colitis, seizures, lactic acidosis, myelosuppression, including anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia. DRUG INTERACTIONS: Serotonin syndrome, characterized by fever, agitation, mental status changes, and tremors, has been reported infrequently following concomitant administration of linezolid and a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
OXAZOLIDINONE ANTIBACTERIALS
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Myelosuppression has been reported. Monitor serial CBC with differential. For severe neutropenia, administer colony stimulating factor (eg, filgrastim, sargramostim). Transfusions as needed for severe thrombocytopenia, bleeding. For seizures, administer IV benzodiazepines; barbiturates or propofol may be needed if seizures persist or recur.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Not recommended because of potential for seizures. HOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal in a patient with a recent, substantial overdose who is alert or in whom airway is protected.
  • Antidote: None
  • Airway management: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required in patients with severe seizures.
  • Myelosuppression: For severe neutropenia, administer colony stimulating factor. Filgrastim 5 mcg/kg/day subQ or IV over 15 to 30 minutes OR sargramostim 250 mcg/meter(2)/day IV over 4 hours. Transfusion of platelets, packed red cells, or both may be needed in patients with severe thrombocytopenia, anemia, or hemorrhage.
  • Serotonin syndrome: Concomitant use of linezolid with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor has resulted in a serotonin syndrome; this is attributed to linezolid's action as a weak reversible monoamine oxidase inhibitor. Primary treatment is sedation with IV benzodiazepines, and cooling measures. CYPROHEPTADINE: A serotonin antagonist with high affinity for the 5-HT2 receptors; effective for milder cases of serotonin syndrome. Dose: ADULT: 12 mg orally or nasogastric tube, followed by 4 to 8 mg every 4 to 6 hours. CHILD: 0.25 mg/kg/day orally or nasogastric tube divided every 6 hours, maximum dose 12 mg/day. CHLORPROMAZINE: A phenothiazine antipsychotic with 5-HT2 antagonist activity; indicated in severe serotonin syndrome cases. Dose: 12.5 to 50 mg IV, followed by 25 to 50 mg every 6 hours. It is NOT generally recommended because it may cause severe hypotension. Severe cases have been managed with benzodiazepine sedation and neuromuscular paralysis with nondepolarizing agents.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs and liver enzymes in symptomatic patients. Monitor serial CBC (with differential) and platelet count. Myelosuppression, including anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia have been reported in patients receiving linezolid. Monitor serum electrolyte status in patients with significant diarrhea and/or vomiting. Monitor for clinical evidence of serotonin syndrome.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: During a phase I clinical trial, approximately 30% of a dose of linezolid was removed during a 3-hour hemodialysis session that began 3 hours after administration of the dose. Hemodialysis should only be considered in patients with severe toxicity not responding to supportive care.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: A patient with an inadvertent exposure, that remains asymptomatic can be managed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: All patients with deliberate self-harm ingestions should be evaluated in a health care facility and monitored until symptoms resolve. Patients with unintentional ingestions who are symptomatic should be observed in a healthcare facility. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients who remain symptomatic despite adequate treatment should be admitted. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
OXAZOLIDINONE ANTIBACTERIALS
TOXICITY: A specific minimum toxic dose has not been established. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: LINEZOLID: ADULT: Varies by indication. Recommended dose is 400 to 600 mg IV or orally every 12 hr for 10 to 28 days depending on the indication. PEDIATRIC: PRETERM NEONATES (Less than 34 weeks), LESS THAN 7 DAYS OF AGE: Recommended initial dose is 10 mg/kg every 12 hr; some neonates may require dosing of 10 mg/kg 8 hr. NEONATES AND CHILDREN 11 YEARS AND YOUNGER: 10 mg/kg orally or IV every 8 to 12 hours depending on indication. TEDIZOLID: ADULT: 200 mg once daily orally or as an IV infusion over 1 hour once daily for 6 days. PEDIATRIC: Safety and effectiveness have not been established in pediatric patients.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report use of a MAO inhibitor within the last 14 days prior to initiating therapy.
  • This drug may cause diarrhea, nausea, or headache.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of myelosuppression, lactic acidosis (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, tachypnea), or changes in vision..
  • Advise patient not to skip doses and complete full course of therapy.
  • Patient should avoid consumption of large quantities of foods or beverages with a high tyramine content (greater than 100 mg tyramine per meal). Examples of high-tyramine containing foods are aged cheese, dried/processed meats, alcohol, sauerkraut, soy sauce, or yeast extract/supplements.
  • Advise patient to consult healthcare professional prior to taking products containing pseudoephedrine or phenylpropanolamine.
